required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Improving Spine Surgical Care With Real-Time Objective Patient Tracking Using the Apple Watch
clinical_study.official_title: Improving Spine Surgical Care With Real-Time Objective Patient Tracking Using the Apple Watch

brief_summary.textblock: One of the primary goals of spine surgery is to reduce pain and increase mobility to improve patients' quality of life. Currently, there is no established method for surgeons to objectively track their patients' mobilization postoperatively. This study is the first prospective trial utilizing the Apple Watch to objectively track patients before and after elective spine surgery. The investigators hypothesize that the ability of patients to track their own activity and discuss with their surgeon objective mobilization goals will not only help patients achieve empowerment in their own care but also improve their overall satisfaction and self-reported outcomes after spine surgery.

primary_outcome.measure: Correlation between Objective Patient Measures (Steps, Distance Travelled, etc from Apple Watch) and Patient-Reported Outcome Measures (SF-36, EQ-5D, PROMIS, NDI, ODI, VAS)
primary_outcome.description: Short Form-36 (SF-36): Scores range from 0 to 100. Higher scores indicate better health outcomes. EuroQOL-5 Dimensional Questionnaire (EQ-5D): Scores range from 0 to 100. Higher scores indicate better health outcomes. Patient-Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System (PROMIS): Scores range from 41 to 78.3. Higher scores indicate worse health outcomes. Neck Disability Index (NDI): Scores range from 0 to 100. Higher scores indicate worse health outcomes. Oswestry Disability Index (ODI): Scores range from 0 to 100. Higher scores indicate worse health outcomes. Visual Analog Scale (VAS): Scores range from 0 to 100 mm. Higher scores indicate worse health outcomes.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Objective Outcome Measures (Steps, Distance Travelled, etc from Apple Watch) Before and After Surgery
primary_outcome.time_frame: 2-6 weeks pre-operatively; 4-6 weeks, 3 months, 6 months, and 12 months post-operatively

primary_outcome.measure: Patient Compliance with Wearing Apple Watch
Patient Compliance with Wearing Apple Watch

Patient Satisfaction with their Spine Care
Patient Satisfaction with their Spine Care

arm_group.description: Participants will receive standard care, and an Apple Watch to record activity through the App.

intervention.description: Participants in the Apple Watch and App arm will receive an Apple Watch and download an App (NeuroCoach). The Apple Watch and App are used for this study to record patient's mobility information (e.g., step counts, heart rate, stairs climbed, distance traveled) as well as provide an additional platform for patients to complete questionnaires.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- English-speaking.
- Undergoing elective spine surgery by attending physicians at Stanford University.
- Own iPhone
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients with spine trauma, tumors, or infection.

overall_official.affiliation: Department of Neurosurgery at Stanford University

clinical_study.keyword: Objective Tracking of Spine Surgery Outcomes
